title: China Eximbank provides $119 million buyer’s credit loan for 340 km Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#57039, #54079)
description: On July 29, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Sudan signed a $3 billion oil-backed master framework agreement (or line of credit) to finance various infrastructure projects (as captured via Project ID#57039). This resources-credit cooperation package is backed by future revenues from the sale of oil exports. Each subsidiary buyer’s credit loan (BCL) issued through the framework agreement carries a 15-year maturity and 5.6% interest rate.  One of the subsidiary loans approved through this agreement in 2009 was a $119 million BCL for the 340 km Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project.  The proceeds of the loan were used to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $220 million commercial contract with Sinohydro.   The project involved the construction of a 340 km road from the city of Renk (الرنك) in Upper Nile State to the city of Malakal (ملكال) in Upper Nile State.   Sinohydro was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A foundation stone laying ceremony took place on April 21, 2009. However, Sinohydro reportedly halted construction with only 180 km of the road completed. It is unclear whether the Chinese contractor ever finished this project.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan issued for the Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project may have underperformed vis-a-vis lender expectations. According to Sudan’s Finance Minister Ali Mahmood Abdel-Rasool, China Eximbank suspended its financing for 11 projects in Sudan following the secession of South Sudan in July 2011, which triggered a major loss of oil revenue (a key source of collateral for China Eximbank loans). Ali Mahmood Abdel-Rasool said at the time that the Government of Sudan had previously pledged oil revenues (worth 120,000 barrels per day) to China Eximbank as a source of collateral. Then, on February 18, 2012, the Chinese Government announced that it had agreed to reschedule the outstanding debt obligations of the Government of Sudan by extending loan repayment periods by 5 years (as captured via Project ID#30421). According to the External Debt Unit of the Central Bank of Sudan, the Government of Sudan's total arrears to Chinese creditors amounted to $3.864 billion ($2.608 billion in principal, $1.129 billion in interest, and $127 million in penalty interest) as of March 31, 2022.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 兰克-马拉卡勒公路项目 or 和平之路.2. SAIS-CARI identifies the loan's maturity as 20 years and its interest rate as 3.5%.  For the time being, AidData relies on the maturity and interest rate that were supposed to apply to all subsidiary loans approved through the $3 billion oil-backed master framework agreement (see Project ID#57039).3. The 340 km Renk-Malakal Road is part of a larger, $650 million Western Salvation Highway, which links Khartoum to Western states in Darfur (captured via Project ID#54079). Financing for the other roads that make up the Western Salvation Highway is captured via Project ID#1050, ID#1051, ID#1053, and ID#1013.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $119 million buyer’s credit loan for 340 km Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#57039, #54079)

# Description
On July 29, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Sudan signed a $3 billion oil-backed master framework agreement (or line of credit) to finance various infrastructure projects (as captured via Project ID#57039). This resources-credit cooperation package is backed by future revenues from the sale of oil exports. Each subsidiary buyer’s credit loan (BCL) issued through the framework agreement carries a 15-year maturity and 5.6% interest rate.  One of the subsidiary loans approved through this agreement in 2009 was a $119 million BCL for the 340 km Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project.  The proceeds of the loan were used to be used by the borrower to partially finance a $220 million commercial contract with Sinohydro.   The project involved the construction of a 340 km road from the city of Renk (الرنك) in Upper Nile State to the city of Malakal (ملكال) in Upper Nile State.   Sinohydro was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A foundation stone laying ceremony took place on April 21, 2009. However, Sinohydro reportedly halted construction with only 180 km of the road completed. It is unclear whether the Chinese contractor ever finished this project.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan issued for the Renk-Malakal Road Construction Project may have underperformed vis-a-vis lender expectations. According to Sudan’s Finance Minister Ali Mahmood Abdel-Rasool, China Eximbank suspended its financing for 11 projects in Sudan following the secession of South Sudan in July 2011, which triggered a major loss of oil revenue (a key source of collateral for China Eximbank loans). Ali Mahmood Abdel-Rasool said at the time that the Government of Sudan had previously pledged oil revenues (worth 120,000 barrels per day) to China Eximbank as a source of collateral. Then, on February 18, 2012, the Chinese Government announced that it had agreed to reschedule the outstanding debt obligations of the Government of Sudan by extending loan repayment periods by 5 years (as captured via Project ID#30421). According to the External Debt Unit of the Central Bank of Sudan, the Government of Sudan's total arrears to Chinese creditors amounted to $3.864 billion ($2.608 billion in principal, $1.129 billion in interest, and $127 million in penalty interest) as of March 31, 2022.
justification: Road construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 340 km road construction, general transportation infrastructure

title: Chinese Government funds construction of school in Nyala (linked to #57170)
description: On September 5, 2009, the Chinese ambassador to the Sudan, Li Chengwen, and the Deputy Governor of South Darfur State, Abdel Aziz Adam al-Hilu, inaugurated the newly completed Chinese-built school in Nyala, South Darfur State, Sudan called the China-Sudan Friendship Primary School. The school has 32 classrooms, six teachers' offices, 600 sets of chairs and desks, and a small football pitch.  The school was constructed by the engineering troops of the Chinese peacekeeping forces in Darfur in their spare time. The value and start date are unknown. In 2012, Chinese peacekeepers initiated another project to renovate this school (#57170).
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government funds construction of school in Nyala (linked to #57170)

# Description
On September 5, 2009, the Chinese ambassador to the Sudan, Li Chengwen, and the Deputy Governor of South Darfur State, Abdel Aziz Adam al-Hilu, inaugurated the newly completed Chinese-built school in Nyala, South Darfur State, Sudan called the China-Sudan Friendship Primary School. The school has 32 classrooms, six teachers' offices, 600 sets of chairs and desks, and a small football pitch.  The school was constructed by the engineering troops of the Chinese peacekeeping forces in Darfur in their spare time. The value and start date are unknown. In 2012, Chinese peacekeepers initiated another project to renovate this school (#57170).
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of primary school with classrooms, offices, and sports facilities

title: China donates musical instruments to South Sudan
description: On February 16, 2009 in Khartoum, China's Ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen and the Government of South Sudan Minster of Culture Abino Akur Akur attended a ceremony for the donation of instruments from China to the South Sudanese government. The musical instruments amounted to 64 pieces, including violoncellos, violins, trombones and others. The amount is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. South Sudan state was founded on July 9, 2011. This donation was made to the Southern Sudan Autonomous Region.
combined_text:

OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title

The musical instruments amounted to 64 pieces, including violoncellos, violins, trombones and others. The amount is unknown.
justification: Project involves cultural donation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Chinese government donates 20 million RMB in Humanitarian aid to Darfur
description: On June 1, 2009 in Khartoum, Sudan, the Chinese special envoy for Sudan for the Darfur issue, Liu Guijin, met today with the Sudanese President Omer Al-Bashir to attend the signing ceremony of a humanitarian aid grant for the three states of Darfur of 20 million CNY. The aid agreement was signed by Sudan's State Minister at the Ministry of International Cooperation, Elias Niamlel, and the Chinese Ambassador to Sudan, in the presence of Liu Guijin.  The current status of the donation and start and end dates are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese government donates 20 million RMB in Humanitarian aid to Darfur

# Description
On June 1, 2009 in Khartoum, Sudan, the Chinese special envoy for Sudan for the Darfur issue, Liu Guijin, met today with the Sudanese President Omer Al-Bashir to attend the signing ceremony of a humanitarian aid grant for the three states of Darfur of 20 million CNY. The aid agreement was signed by Sudan's State Minister at the Ministry of International Cooperation, Elias Niamlel, and the Chinese Ambassador to Sudan, in the presence of Liu Guijin.  The current status of the donation and start and end dates are unknown.
justification: Humanitarian aid donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 20 million CNY humanitarian aid grant for Darfur states, focused on emergency response

title: Financial Support for Election in Sudan (linked to #56848)
description: On December 28, 2009, during a meeting with the Deputy Chairman of the National Commission for the Elections, Dr Abdallah Ahmad Abdallah, the Chinese Ambassador to Sudan announced China would donate 3 million USD in cash assistance to support the upcoming elections in Sudan.  In January 2010, China reiterated its commitment to provide this cash assistance to Sudan for its election in an exchange of letters signed by Chinese Ambassador to Sudan and the Deputy Chairman of the National Commission for the Elections, in which China also promised material assistance (#56848). This aid appears to have been received by Sudan.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Financial Support for Election in Sudan (linked to #56848)

# Description
On December 28, 2009, during a meeting with the Deputy Chairman of the National Commission for the Elections, Dr Abdallah Ahmad Abdallah, the Chinese Ambassador to Sudan announced China would donate 3 million USD in cash assistance to support the upcoming elections in Sudan.  In January 2010, China reiterated its commitment to provide this cash assistance to Sudan for its election in an exchange of letters signed by Chinese Ambassador to Sudan and the Deputy Chairman of the National Commission for the Elections, in which China also promised material assistance (#56848). This aid appears to have been received by Sudan.
justification: Project involves financial support for elections without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Cash assistance for election support, no energy or infrastructure components

title: CNPC grants 3 million USD to Sudan Poverty-Stricken Mother's Charity
description: On November 19, 2009, CNPC signed an agreement with the Sudan Poverty-Stricken Mothers Charity Society to donate 3 million USD over three years. CNPC will donate 1 million USD to the institution to promote education, production, and living conditions each year. At least 50% of the funds will be used in Darfur area.  The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

CNPC will donate 1 million USD to the institution to promote education, production, and living conditions each year. At least 50% of the funds will be used in Darfur area.  The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

description: According to the Economic and Commercial Counsellor's Office of the Embassy of the People's Republic of China in Sudan, two batches of anti-malaria medicine have arrived at Khartoum in October 2009. Some anti-malaria equipment will arrive in Sudan soon.

title: Chinese Government dispatches 29th Chinese medical team to Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital and Omdurman Friendship Hospital
description: The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Sudan every two years since April 1971. Shaanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.  On 25 March 2009, China’s Ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen and Sudan’s Minister of Health, Tabita Shukayi, signed a protocol agreement dispatching the 29th medical team to Sudan. The 36-member team was stationed at the Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital and Omdurman Friendship Hospital, both of which were previously built with funding from the Chinese Government. The team completed its term of service between 24 August, 2009 and September 2011.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 29th Chinese medical team to Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital and Omdurman Friendship Hospital

# Description
The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Sudan every two years since April 1971. Shaanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.  On 25 March 2009, China’s Ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen and Sudan’s Minister of Health, Tabita Shukayi, signed a protocol agreement dispatching the 29th medical team to Sudan. The 36-member team was stationed at the Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital and Omdurman Friendship Hospital, both of which were previously built with funding from the Chinese Government. The team completed its term of service between 24 August, 2009 and September 2011.
justification: Project involves medical assistance and healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Dispatching medical team to hospitals, healthcare focus, no energy-related components
